text: Out of curiosity has anyone tried their hand at algotrading on financial markets?

elements.text: Out of curiosity has anyone tried their hand at algotrading on financial markets?

text:
I did many years ago. But don't bother now as it'll cause problems with my day job (I'm an IT contractor at a bank). Also, it costs a lot more to do algo trading in financials. You need thousands of pounds in margin if you want to just trade single futures contracts. Plus expensive data feeds. It might costs upwards of £2k a month in connectivity and data fees. And one flash crash can wipe out a year or more of profits.

With Betfair, you can realistically start with under £100. You can rent a server to run your bot for under £10 a month. (In my experience) it's easier to find an edge. You get better diversification benefits, due to the hundreds of uncorrelated markets that trade every day. A flash crash wont' wipe out a years worth of profits.

A negative point of doing Betfair vs Financials is that Betfair is probably (in general) less scalable than financials. But that isn't to say that you can't make more than enough to feed your family using Betfair.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

text: Also on Betfair if your algo goes rogue you're not going to have a fight with the US to avoid spending the next 40 years in a federal prison cell!!!!

elements.text: Also on Betfair if your algo goes rogue you're not going to have a fight with the US to avoid spending the next 40 years in a federal prison cell!!!!

text:
Yeah, I looked into it a while back and even backtested some stuff and set up with Interactive Brokers for the market access. 

In the end, if you’re an individual, betting markets just make more sense. Higher returns for less risk. Sports markets have thousands of independent events every day, whereas financials are all so inter-related that it’s hard to remove all systemic risk (even if you close out every day). You need so much more money to get started in financials and you’d be competing against the biggest and smartest institutions. Without a really defined niche it’s hard to compete I think.

elements.text: Yeah, I looked into it a while back and even backtested some stuff and set up with Interactive Brokers for the market access.

Sports markets have thousands of independent events every day, whereas financials are all so inter-related that it’s hard to remove all systemic risk (even if you close out every day). You need so much more money to get started in financials and you’d be competing against the biggest and smartest institutions. Without a really defined niche it’s hard to compete I think.

text: With financials you have to overcome the transaction charges before you even get anywhere. Betting exchanges are generous from that respect.

elements.text: With financials you have to overcome the transaction charges before you even get anywhere. Betting exchanges are generous from that respect.

text: Agreed barriers to entry are higher but potential rewards also high, and if you're a small group that cost gets dampened. Flash crashes only an issue if you're highly leveraged no? Also, Quantopian seems interesting in the sense that you can potentially have institutional backing.

elements.text: Agreed barriers to entry are higher but potential rewards also high, and if you're a small group that cost gets dampened. Flash crashes only an issue if you're highly leveraged no? Also, Quantopian seems interesting in the sense that you can potentially have institutional backing.

text:
With no leverage how much money would you need to put at risk to make 7 figures a year for example? With sports it’s probably 100k. For financials it’ll be at least 7 figures. Probably 8 figures. With financials you basically need leverage but then you’re just increasing risk. 
(Edit: with sports you probably need even less to start with if you’re allowed to compound)

elements.text: With no leverage how much money would you need to put at risk to make 7 figures a year for example? With sports it’s probably 100k. For financials it’ll be at least 7 figures. Probably 8 figures. With financials you basically need leverage but then you’re just increasing risk.
(Edit: with sports you probably need even less to start with if you’re allowed to compound)

text:
Diversification is definitely a good argument, but personally I’d put money into something completely unrelated, or just invest the money long term. Much like what you’d do with spare money or savings in a regular job. 

There’s always a risk that sports betting will become unviable over night. But then anyone can lose their job overnight as well.

text: For CFDs I used 2 different brokers, one would set a fixed fee for opening/closing orders which would make it much more expensive than the other for smaller orders, but had better spreads and a better service overall, the other was much better in terms of promotions and leverage - was also dodgy AF lol. Nowadays the rules have changed by some EU regularions and leverage is capped ar 1:30...I used to have 1:500 and 1:1000 xD
